org.domainobject.jetlag.core.funclib

Annotation Type VarArgsParam


  • @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Target(value=METHOD)
public @interface VarArgsParam
    The VarArgsParameter parameter describes a parameter denoting variable argument list. Contrary to Java, a varargs parameter in a Jetlag function does not have to be the last parameter. Also, the arguments expressing the varargs parameter can cycle in tuples, triples, etc. through multiple types. A typical example would be a function that maps an input value to an output value, outputting a default value if the input value could not be mapped. For example: 
            map(role, 'King', 0, 'President', 1, 'Minister', 2, 3)
    Here, all arguments from "King" to "2" express the varargs parameter while "3" is again a "normal" argument. The arguments expressing the varargs parameter are repeating tuples of a string argument and an integer argument, resepectively. The Java parameter corresponding to a Jetlag varargs parameter must not be a varargs parameter, not even when no cycling through multiple types takes place. A Jetlag varargs parameter must be implemented as a regular Java array. The class of the array elements must be capable of being instantiated with the user-provided tuples or triples through its constructor (a two-arg constructor for tuples, a three-arg contructor for triples). Alternatively, you can also specify or through an applicable factory method.

    Example

            @Function()
        @Description("Map strings to integers")
        @Param("The string to map")
        @VarArgsParam(
                factoryClass = StringIntTuple.class // Class capable of creating a
                                                                                        // StringIntTuple. Can be omitted if
                                                                                        // that class is StringIntTuple
                                                                                        // itself
                factoryMethod = "valueOf"
                varArgs = {
                        @VarArg(uiName = "match_against",
                                description = "The string to compare the input string with"),
                        @VarArg(uiName = "output",
                                description = "The number to output if the input string was equal to the match candidate")
                }
        )
        @Param("The number to output if the input did not match any of the match candidates")
        @Return("The integer that the input string mapped to or the specified default value")
        public int map(CallInfo info, String role, StringIntTuple[] mappings, int dfault) {
                for(StringIntTuple mapping : mappings) {
                        if(role.equals(mapping.getString()) {
                                return mapping.getInt();
                        }
                }
                return dfault;
        }
    Author:
    Ayco Holleman

      Class<?> factoryClass
      The class upon which to invoke the static factory method.
      String factoryMethod
      The name of the factory method.
